docs.title: Higher Education
docs.text: FAQ for Higher Education Institutions

docs.title: What is the primary purpose of the Heartland Cyber Range, and how does it align with our institution's educational goals?
docs.text: The primary purpose of the Heartland Cyber Range is to provide a cutting-edge and adaptable environment for comprehensive cybersecurity education, training, and research.

docs.title: How will the Heartland Cyber Range benefit our students and faculty in cybersecurity and related programs?
docs.text:
Many cybersecurity teams often encounter various types of cyber threats, such as ransomware attacks, cloud breaches, or supply chain vulnerabilities, without prior exposure. However, by leveraging the comprehensive library of real-world learning modules and exercises, students can gain hands-on experience in a wide array of real-world scenarios.

The Heartland Cyber Range empowers students to enter the workforce with a distinct advantage, enabling them to meet their employers' demands effectively.

docs.title: What types of exercises and scenarios are available for students and faculty to practice on?
docs.text: Scenarios mimic real-world situations and put students in various roles to practice in during cyberattack simulations such as ransomware attacks and active breaches. Exercises promote exploration around a certain topic or tool and allow the student the freedom to complete a task in whatever way they choose. Both scenarios and exercises are built to allow the student to put into practice what they’ve learned in the classroom and while on the range.

docs.title: Can the cyber range accommodate various skill levels, from beginners to advanced learners?
docs.text: Yes, there are different levels of difficulty settings for the exercises within the Heartland Cyber Range to accommodate students of varying skill levels. We understand that cybersecurity education should be inclusive and adaptable to the experience and expertise of each student. Therefore, the range offers exercises and challenges in a tiered fashion, allowing students to choose their appropriate difficulty level.

docs.title: How is the cyber range maintained and kept up to date with the latest threats and technologies?
docs.text: We have a team to curate content and ensure it is relevant and current to today’s cybersecurity landscape.

docs.title: What are the technical requirements and infrastructure needed to support the cyber range on our campus?
docs.text:
To access the Heartland Cyber Range, students will need the following:

  • Internet Connection: The Heartland Cyber Range is browser-based, so a stable internet connection is essential. We recommend a broadband or high-speed connection to ensure a seamless experience.

  • Web Browser: Any modern web browser will work. Popular choices like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, or Safari are all compatible. Please ensure your browser is up to date for the best performance and security.

  • Computer or Device: Students can use a desktop computer, laptop, or tablet, if it supports a compatible web browser. While a larger screen and full-sized keyboard are preferable for the best experience, the cyber range is designed to be responsive and usable on various devices.

  • Operating System: The Heartland Cyber Range is platform-agnostic. It can be accessed from Windows, macOS or Linux operating systems.

docs.title: Is the Heartland Cyber Range cloud-based or on-premises, and what are the implications for our network and IT infrastructure?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range is hosted on a horizontally distributed edge-based network across Kansas and Western Missouri, and the only requirement from the school network is access to the platform via internet connectivity. The Heartland Cyber Range does not interfere with the institution’s existing network setup.

docs.title: Can students access the Heartland Cyber Range remotely or is it restricted to on-campus use?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range can be utilized anywhere with an internet connection, providing both in-class and self-paced opportunities for students to practice outside of the classroom. As it provides a simulated environment for hands on experience, it can be used to practice any skills and knowledge gained from traditional curriculum.

docs.title: What support and training resources are available to faculty who want to use the Heartland Cyber Range in their courses?
docs.text: Support and technical assistance are readily available for both teachers and students encountering difficulties while using the Heartland Cyber Range. We understand that effective support is crucial to a successful learning experience.

docs.title: Can the Heartland Cyber Range be customized to fit our institution's specific needs and curriculum?
docs.text:
Yes, Phase II of the Heartland Cyber Range will allow faculty to create customized content that is relevant to what students are learning in the textbook. Faculty can create custom labs, scenarios, or exercises with the drag-and-drop functionality to complement their existing curriculum.

Faculty will also create custom learning pathways for students by selecting available content in the HCR library and sequencing the preferred pathway. This provides faculty with the ability to create a customized learning experience that many other cyber ranges don’t offer.

docs.title: What kind of technical support and troubleshooting resources are available for students and faculty using the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text:
There are several ways to get support:

  • There is a support link that may be used while signed in to the range.

  • On the official HCR Discord #help channel: #help

  • By emailing support@heartlandcyberrange.com

docs.title: What opportunities exist for ongoing research and development related to cybersecurity within the Heartland Cyber Range environment, and how can our faculty and students get involved?
docs.text:
The Heartland Cyber Range environment presents numerous opportunities for ongoing research and development. Our platform is designed to be a versatile and adaptable sandbox environment, making it an ideal setting for exploring cutting-edge research initiatives.

Faculty and students interested in getting involved in research can leverage the Heartland Cyber Range in the following ways:

  • Adaptable Research Environment: The Heartland Cyber Range provides a secure and flexible environment where researchers can simulate real-world cyber threats and scenarios. This adaptability allows for the development and testing of new cybersecurity strategies, technologies, and tools.

  • Custom Research Inquiries: We encourage faculty and students to contact us with specific research inquiries and project proposals. Whether you are exploring innovative techniques for threat detection, vulnerability analysis, or any other cybersecurity-related research, our team can assist in customizing the platform to meet your research needs.

  • Collaboration Opportunities: The Heartland Cyber Range is committed to fostering collaboration between academic institutions and industry. We welcome partnerships with faculty and students to jointly address research challenges, share insights, and develop solutions to emerging threats.

  • Educational Integration: Researchers can also explore opportunities for integrating their findings and innovations into educational programs, ensuring that the next generation of cybersecurity professionals benefit from the latest research outcomes.

docs.title: K-12 Administrators
docs.text: FAQ for K-12 Administrators

docs.title: What is the cost associated with implementing the Heartland Cyber Range in our district?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range will be available at no cost to K-12 students and staff through initial funding by the Kansas Department of Commerce, industry sponsorships, and continuous premium license model.

docs.title: How will the cyber range curriculum integrate with our existing educational programs?
docs.text:
The Heartland Cyber Range content aligns with the industry recognized NICE Framework, which is a nationally recognized framework developed by the U.S. government to help individuals and organizations identify, categorize, and understand the various roles and specialties within cybersecurity. The NICE Framework helps educational institutions and training providers align programs with the needs of the cybersecurity workforce. This ensures that students and trainees acquire the relevant skills and knowledge for their chosen career paths within their Heartland Cyber Range experience.

In addition, the range provides a simulated environment to practice and obtain real world experience – any knowledge and skills gained through traditional curriculum can be put into practice on the range.

docs.title: What age groups and grade levels is the cyber range designed for?
docs.text: All age groups and grade levels (K-12, and 2 &4 year higher ed) will have appropriate courses available. Once a student graduates, they will be provided with an electronic token that will allow them to access the achievements earned while using the range to provide potential employers, as well as to continue to access the range as an adult and grow their experience profile.

docs.title: What security measures are in place to protect students' personal information and data?
docs.text: We only retain data necessary to allow for use of online services, and that data is encrypted with [encryption type]. All other data is anonymized or deleted as soon as it is no longer needed. Additionally, our Terms of Use require that students under 18 require consent to use the range from a parent or legal guardian, and that only a parent or legal guardian my provide information for children 13 or under in compliance with COPPA (Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act).

docs.title: How do students access and use the cyber range platform?
docs.text:
To access the Heartland Cyber Range, your students will need the following:

  • Internet Connection: The Heartland Cyber Range is browser-based, so a stable internet connection is essential. We recommend a broadband or high-speed connection to ensure a seamless experience.

  • Web Browser: Any modern web browser will work. Popular choices like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, or Safari are all compatible. Please ensure your browser is up to date for the best performance and security.

  • Computer or Device: Your students can use a desktop computer, laptop, or tablet, if it supports a compatible web browser. While a larger screen and full-sized keyboard are preferable for the best experience, the cyber range is designed to be responsive and usable on various devices.

  • Operating System: The Heartland Cyber Range is platform-agnostic. It can be accessed from Windows, macOS or Linux operating systems.

docs.title: What technical support is provided to our teachers and students?
docs.text:
There are several ways to get support:

  • There is a support link that may be used while signed in to the range.

  • On the official HCR Discord #help channel: https://discord.gg/3T4aUKrket

  • By emailing support@heartlandcyberrange.com

docs.title: Can the cyber range be customized to fit the specific needs and goals of our district?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range is designed with educators in mind. You can easily set up exercises and challenges to teach specific cybersecurity concepts in a way that's engaging and informative for your students.

docs.title: K-12 Teachers
docs.text: FAQ for K-12 Teachers

docs.title: What is the Heartland Cyber Range, and how can it benefit K-12 students?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range is a virtual, interactive environment designed to simulate real-world networks, systems, and applications for cybersecurity education, cyber defense training, and cyber technology research and development. The Heartland Cyber Range provides a safe, secure environment where students, researchers, industry professionals, and government can strengthen theoretical learning alongside practical training on the latest threats and tactics to be better prepared for the realities of defending a network or against an actual attack.

docs.title: What students are best targeted to utilize the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text: We are committed to ensuring that the Heartland Cyber Range is accessible to all K-12 students, regardless of their skill level and prior experience.

docs.title: What is the cost for K-12 students to utilize the range?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range will be available at no cost to K-12 students and staff through initial funding by the Kansas Department of Commerce, industry sponsorships, and a premium license model.

docs.title: How do I sign up / get started?
docs.text: As of 4/5/2024, we are accepting requests to join the Beta program before launch. Please contact support@heartlandcyberrange.com

docs.title: What technology and equipment do my students need to access and use the cyber range?
docs.text:
To access the Heartland Cyber Range, your students will need the following:

  • Internet Connection: The Heartland Cyber Range is browser-based, so a stable internet connection is essential. We recommend a broadband or high-speed connection to ensure a seamless experience.

  • Web Browser: Any modern web browser will work. Popular choices like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, or Safari are all compatible. Please ensure your browser is up to date for the best performance and security.

  • Computer or Device: Your students can use a desktop computer, laptop, or tablet, if it supports a compatible web browser. While a larger screen and full-sized keyboard are preferable for the best experience, the cyber range is designed to be responsive and usable on various devices.

  • Operating System: The Heartland Cyber Range is platform-agnostic. It can be accessed from Windows, macOS or Linux operating systems.

docs.title: What type(s) of content is available in the range?
docs.text: When it launches, the Heartland Cyber Range will start with over 75 different courses, labs, scenarios, and exercises that span across several different cybersecurity topics. The content varies in level of difficulty from entry level to advanced, and new content will be constantly added to expand learning pathways and offerings, and to keep information fresh and relevant to today’s security landscape.

docs.title: How can I integrate the Heartland Cyber Range into my existing curriculum and lesson plans effectively?
docs.text:
The Heartland Cyber Range can be utilized anywhere with an internet connection, providing both in-school and out of school opportunities for students to practice at home. As it provides a simulated environment for hands on experience, it can be used to practice any skills and knowledge gained from traditional curriculum.

All content aligns with the industry recognized NICE Framework, which is a nationally recognized framework developed by the U.S. government to help individuals and organizations identify, categorize, and understand the various roles and specialties within cybersecurity.

With the Heartland Cyber Range Phase II actively being developed, teachers will have the flexibility to curate personalized learning pathways and craft tailored lesson plans for students by selecting specific content from the extensive library.

docs.title: Can students work on the cyber range from home or is it limited to in-school use only?
docs.text: Students can access and work on the Heartland Cyber range from the convenience of their own homes. Our platform is designed to be accessible remotely, allowing students to engage with the range from anywhere with an internet connection.

docs.title: What support or technical assistance is available for teachers and students encountering difficulties while using the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text: Support and technical assistance are readily available for both teachers and students encountering difficulties while using the Heartland Cyber Range. We understand that effective support is crucial to a successful learning experience.

docs.title: Are there any training or resources available for teachers to better utilize the cyber range in their classrooms?
docs.text: Yes, a user guide for teachers on how to utilize the range will be made available following its launch.

docs.title: How can I ensure that my students' privacy and data are protected while using the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text: Our Terms of Use dictate that children under 18 have their parent’s consent to use the range, and that information for students 13 or under may only be provided by the parent or legal guardian, in accordance with COPPA (Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act).

docs.title: Can I use the Heartland Cyber Range to teach specific cybersecurity concepts or skills in my curriculum?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range is designed with educators in mind. You can easily set up exercises and challenges to teach specific cybersecurity concepts in a way that's engaging and informative for your students.

docs.title: Are there different levels or difficulty settings for the exercises to accommodate students of varying skill levels?
docs.text: Yes, there are different levels of difficulty settings for the exercises within the Heartland Cyber Range to accommodate students of varying skill levels. We understand that cybersecurity education should be inclusive and adaptable to the experience and expertise of each student. Therefore, the range offers exercises and challenges in a tiered fashion, allowing students to choose their appropriate difficulty level.

docs.title: How will the Heartland Cyber Range align with existing curriculum standards?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range content aligns with the industry recognized NICE Framework, which is a nationally recognized framework developed by the U.S. government to help individuals and organizations identify, categorize, and understand the various roles and specialties within cybersecurity. The NICE Framework helps educational institutions and training providers align programs with the needs of the cybersecurity workforce. This ensures that students and trainees acquire the relevant skills and knowledge for their chosen career paths within their Heartland Cyber Range experience.

docs.title: Organizations
docs.text: FAQ for Higher Education Institutions

docs.title: What is the Heartland Cyber Range, and how can it benefit my organization?
docs.text:
The Heartland Cyber Range is a virtual learning and research platform that emulates real-world networks, systems, and applications. The Range serves as an interactive learning and assessment environment to improve practical cybersecurity skills and knowledge of real-world challenges. The Range also provides a threat simulation environment for cybersecurity research, new product development and product testing in a secure and controlled environment to help fortify our regional cybersecurity defenses so we can better protect our region’s citizens, enterprises, and critical infrastructure.

Competency Testing & Credentialing - Employers must understand the knowledge, skills and abilities employees and potential candidates possess. The Cyber Range provides employers with the analytic tools to know, with certainty that a competency has been obtained

Threat Analysis & Simulation - The Cyber Range offers a safe environment to help IT and cybersecurity staff evaluate an organization's defenses against malware, network updates, and other attack vectors. The Range also assists critical infrastructure groups in simulating operating environments and allows teams to strategize how best to handle the latest cyber threats.

docs.title: What sets the HCR apart from competitors?
docs.text: The state-of-the-art network that runs the Heartland Cyber Range provides for unparalleled performance and availability, and the ability to create custom scenarios and learning pathways are options not found in other ranges. Aside from content available for education and training, future phases will allow for red/blue/purple team simulations, virtual infrastructure overlays, and sandboxed environments for testing software, simulating cyberattacks, and evaluating security postures.

docs.title: Is the HCR suitable for the size of my organization?
docs.text:
The HCR was designed to be accessible and beneficial to organizations of all sizes.

Here's how the HCR can be used effectively by all organizations, regardless of size:

  • The HCR was designed to be scalable, accommodating the needs of small, medium-sized, and large organizations. Organizations can tailor its usage to match the specific requirements of the organization.

  • The HCR can be customized to focus on the specific cybersecurity skills and knowledge your organization needs, ensuring that training aligns with your unique requirements.

  • Cyber threats and attacks don't discriminate by organization size. The cyber range offers a safe environment for all organizations to practice and prepare for real-world threats.

  • For smaller organizations with limited cybersecurity expertise, the HCR provides a structured and effective way to develop and enhance their team's cybersecurity skills.

  • Small organizations can also benefit from cost-effective plans that allow them to access valuable cybersecurity training and testing resources without breaking the budget.

docs.title: Do you have case studies or testimonials from other organizations in our industry?
docs.text: Yes, please visit Testimonials - Pending to review testimonials from other industry organizations.

docs.title: Is the cyber range cloud-based or on-premises?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range is cloud-based and be accessed through a web-browser, so there is no need to purchase additional hardware.

docs.title: What types of cybersecurity scenarios can be simulated in the cyber range?
docs.text:
The Heartland Cyber Range will allow hands on experience in the use of tools and software, and simulate real world scenarios to practice the knowledge gained from curriculum. In addition, it will allow for the following types of scenarios:

-Skills validation/upskilling for specific job roles

-Phishing attack awareness training

-Sandboxing for software testing

-CTF (capture the flag) challenges and competitions

-Cyberattack simulations

-Red/blue/purple team engagements

-Scalable research platform

docs.title: Is the cyber range customizable to our organization's specific needs?
docs.text: Yes, Phase II of the Heartland Cyber Range will allow organizations to customize their user experience while accessing the range. Organizations can create custom content and real-world scenarios to simulate the organization’s network environment.

docs.title: What is the level of realism in the simulations?
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range runs on a state-of-the-art platform which provides for seamless performance, no matter where it is being accessed from across the region. In addition, the ability to create custom scenarios and simulations allows for levels of realism not found on other ranges.

docs.title: Can we simulate real-world cyber threats and attacks in the range?
docs.text: Yes, Phase II of the HCR will allow organizations to create and simulate desired real-world cyber threats and attacks in our range.

docs.title: How does the Heartland Cyber Range handle sensitive data and information security?
docs.text: Data security and privacy is a core area of focus in the HCR user experience. All captured performance data is securely stored and transmitted, adhering to best practices and compliance standards to protect user information.

docs.title: Is there a limit to the number of users who can access the cyber range simultaneously?
docs.text: The HCR can currently support up to 7200 simultaneous users accessing the platform. If additional simultaneous users are needed, please contact the HCR staff.

docs.title: What are the hardware and software requirements for accessing the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text:
To access the Heartland Cyber Range, users will need the following:

  • Internet Connection: The Heartland Cyber Range is browser-based, so a stable internet connection is essential. We recommend a broadband or high-speed connection to ensure a seamless experience.

  • Web Browser: Any modern web browser will work. Popular choices like Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, or Safari are all compatible. Please ensure your browser is up-to-date for the best performance and security.

  • Computer or Device: Your students can use a desktop computer, laptop, or tablet, if it supports a compatible web browser. While a larger screen and full-sized keyboard are preferable for the best experience, the cyber range is designed to be responsive and usable on various devices.

docs.title: Is training and support provided for users new to the Heartland Cyber Range?
docs.text: Yes, the Heartland Cyber Range will include walkthroughs on how to best utilize the range, and documentation guides for best practices. The HCR staff will also be available to answer questions and support your organization after registering.

docs.title: Can we track the progress and performance of our cybersecurity teams and individuals in the range?
docs.text: Yes, performance from each user will be captured in the Learning Management System (LMS) and can be monitored by a training administrator.

docs.title: What is the pricing structure for the cyber range?
docs.text: To review the pricing for the Cyber Range, please review the HCR Pricing Page or contact the HCR to inquire for Enterprise licensing.

docs.title: What kind of technical support and assistance is provided to users?
docs.text: Users will have access to comprehensive technical support and assistance. We provide user documentation that offers clear and detailed instructions on how to navigate and utilize the cyber range effectively. Additionally, our staff will be readily available to assist users with any questions, concerns, or technical issues they may encounter during their use of the platform. Our support team is committed to ensuring a seamless and productive experience, making sure users have the resources and assistance they need to make the most of the cyber range.

docs.title: What is the update and maintenance schedule for the cyber range?
docs.text: The HCR will have carefully planned maintenance windows to minimize disruption and ensure the platform remains in peak condition. Users will be notified of scheduled maintenance well in advance so users can plan accordingly.

docs.title: Is there a trial or demo version available for us to evaluate before committing?
docs.text: Yes, the HCR will offer a free trial to organizations that would like to preview the range environment and features. To sign up, please visit the main cyber range page.

docs.title: Are the specific operational hours for the Heartland Cyber Range.
docs.text: The HCR will be always accessible, except for scheduled maintenance periods. These maintenance windows are carefully planned to minimize disruption and ensure the platform remains in peak condition. Our goal is to provide users with the flexibility to engage with the HCR whenever they need it, supporting continuous skill development and training without unnecessary downtime.

docs.title: Can we define specific learning objectives and track progress towards those goals?
docs.text: Yes, Phase II of the HCR will give organizations the ability to create custom learning pathways for employees. Admins can utilize the drag-and-drop feature to create pathways with available content from the HCR library. All user progress is tracked through the Learning Management System (LMS) for employers to review employee results and progress.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This Quick Start Guide is your reference to jumping straight into the Heartland Cyber Range (HCR) platform. This is intended to be a brief introduction to the HCR learning management system (LMS); for more detailed instructions and descriptions, please see the official HCR User Manual.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: Range access is done through the internet – all that is needed is an internet connection and a web browser. The range is compatible with all major browsers such as Chrome, Edge, and Firefox.

docs.title: Logging Into the Range
docs.text:
In your preferred web browser, navigate to: https://learning.heartlandcyberrange.com

  • If you are a new user, click on the link, ‘Click Here to Register as a New User’.
  • If you are a returning user, enter your username and password, then click the ‘Log in’ button.

Alternatively, if you are a returning user and have forgotten your password, click on the ‘Forgot Your Password?’ link for instructions on how to reset your password.

*If logging in for the first time after registering, you may be prompted to verify your email address prior to logging in, if you have not yet done so.

docs.title: Creating an Account
docs.text: When registering as a new user, you will be asked to enter information about yourself. Any required information is indicated with a label. Continue through the questionnaire to the third and final screen which will ask if you have any interest in regional job opportunities. Indicating ‘Yes’ here will make your HCR profile available to our talent exchange platform.

docs.title: User Interface Overview HCR Home  Dashboard  User Profile  Courses  Scenarios  Leaderboards  Compete  Careers  Support

Upon successfully logging in, you will notice a number of different sections in the user interface which are accessible from the navigation bar on the left-side of the screen. We’ll describe each of these below.

The HCR homepage where you can find announcements, news, and other updates related to the HCR.

Your “home” screen is your user dashboard, which gives you quick at-a-glance information about your earned experience and quick links to other sections of the range.

The User Profile section provides additional progress details, statistics, and announcements related to your user profile.

The courses section allows you to view the various courses that are offered and search through them to find the content best suited to your needs.

Practice your skills in real-world situations through scenario-based modules and delve into free form explore modules to practice and learn in your own way.

Find out where you rank compared to other users in experience and learning or through competitive play.

Compete in various challenges and team activities such as solo challenges, red & blue team exercises, and cooperative cyber-attack simulations.

The EKC talent exchange portal, where you can showcase your HCR skills to potential employers and search for your next dream job!

Find options to provide feedback and seek assistance for any issues you encounter while using the HCR.

docs.title: Virtual Machines and Networks
docs.text:
The HCR is a simulation environment – the computers and networks connecting them that you will interact with are all ‘virtualized’. These virtual machines (VMs) and virtual networks can be created on the fly, allowing for massive flexibility and endless options for creating simulations. The EKC network that powers the HCR provides unparalleled performance, allowing VMs to be spun up in a fraction of the time as other ranges.

Any module that requires a VM to complete will contain a button. When you click on it, any VMs associated with the module will be started. Each VM will have an icon associated with it [image placeholder] that when clicked on, will open a ‘console’ view to it in a new tab. Simply click anywhere within this console view to begin interacting with the VM as you would any other computer.

If you begin a lab and are unable to complete it in one setting, any work you have done up to that point will be saved for [update with saved state time] hours. Simply access the lab again, and the VM will be just as you left it. Should you not access the VM within the timeout period, the VM resources will be reclaimed to provide to other users and your work will be lost. Relaunching the lab after this period will start up clean new VMs in their initial state.

When you have finished work in a lab, the VMs and any virtual network resources in use will be reclaimed when you click the [insert ‘complete lab’ button] button. VMs that were in use are ‘destroyed’, meaning any work or information within the VM will be lost, while the resources (RAM, compute, storage) the VM was using will be returned to the EKC network pool.

docs.title: Modules
docs.text: Modules are individual lessons or exercises. They may contain a number of resources such as videos, PDFs, images, etc. Modules may also contain a number of activities such as labs, quizzes, and feedback forms. Scenarios and exercises are modules that allow you to practice and hone the skills you’ve learned. Scenarios mimic real-world situations, and exercises provide goals to achieve while allowing freedom and flexibility to explore.

docs.title: Courses
docs.text: Courses can contain several modules and are typically focused on teaching or providing experience in one particular subject or area. Completing courses can potentially earn a user a badge to indicate proficiency in that area and contribute to completion of learning pathways.

docs.title: Learning Pathways
docs.text: Learning pathways are predefined, curated collections of courses and modules. Learning pathways are designed to help achieve a specific end-goal such as gaining the appropriate experience required to become a Vulnerability and Threat Analyst, as an example. Having the largest scope in terms of content, a learning pathway may cover a broad range of topics so long as they are all aligned with the subject of the learning pathway.

docs.title: Where to Start?
docs.text: Your choice of where to start will depend on your goal. Are you looking for training and experience using a cybersecurity tool you’ve heard about, but are unfamiliar with? Individual modules might be your best option, or even a course if there is one designed for your tool of interest. Maybe instead you have come to the HCR with little to no experience in cybersecurity with an interest in switching careers and breaking into this exciting field; in that case selecting an appropriate learning pathway might be your best option.

docs.title: Selecting and Launching Modules
docs.text: Once you have found a module you would like to try out, simply click on the launch button: Note: The button may indicate ‘Scenario’, ‘Exercise’, or ‘Lab’ depending on the module type. Each module should contain instructions on how to complete it, along with any other supplementary materials you may need (PDFs, Word docs, images, etc.).

docs.title: Competitions and Team Based Exercises
docs.text: Dive in! There are a number of competitive and cooperative events you can take part in. As these involve multiple users, some events may have restrictions on entry; refer to the event description for details. The examples below provide some insight into the types of events that may be available and are not comprehensive.

docs.title: CTF Events
docs.text: Capture the flag events require participants to solve challenges and locate “flags”. Flags are typically a string of text in a specific format to make them obvious upon discovery – check the competition description for details. CTF events can be individual, or team based.

docs.title: Red/Blue/Purple Team Engagements
docs.text: Red vs. blue team engagements are popular amongst corporations looking to improve their security posture and provide training for employees, however there may be community engagements as well that you may sign up for. During the engagement red teams attempt to attack and infiltrate a computer network while blue teams work to defend it. Purple team engagements allow either side to utilize both offensive and defensive capabilities.

docs.title: Cyberattack Simulations
docs.text: Scenarios that simulate particular types of cyberattacks such as phishing campaigns, a ransomware outbreak, or even an active breach by threat actors, for example. Participants may be assigned a particular role and asked to operate in that capacity, in response to the attack.

docs.title: Incident Response and Posture Management
docs.text: Typically a group event, participants are put into incident responder roles. Performance is evaluated with metrics such as response time to resolution. Useful for organizations evaluating their IR teams and can also be set up as a community challenge with better performing teams topping the leaderboards.

docs.title: Responsible Use of the HCR
docs.text: Using a cyber range responsibly is paramount to fostering a secure and constructive learning environment. Responsible use involves adhering to ethical guidelines, respecting the privacy and rights of other users, and refraining from any activities that may cause harm or disruption. Always operate within the designated scope of exercises, refraining from attempting unauthorized actions or exploiting vulnerabilities outside the learning context. Additionally, practicing good cyber hygiene, such as securing your login credentials and reporting any identified vulnerabilities responsibly, contributes to the overall safety and integrity of the cyber range. Responsible use not only promotes a positive learning experience but also reflects the ethical standards expected within the broader cybersecurity community.

When registering as a new user, you will be asked to enter the following information:

  • User type (required) – check the appropriate box based on your situation.
  • First Name & Last Name (required)

Fill out the appropriate information, then click “Continue”.

Finally, indicate your interest in being matched to cybersecurity job opportunities in the region. Indicating “Yes” here will share your user profile, including gained experience and areas of expertise with the EnterpriseKC Talent Exchange.

docs.title: Overview of the Heartland Cyber Range
What Is It
docs.text: The Heartland Cyber Range (HCR) is a virtual, interactive environment designed to simulate real-world networks, systems, and applications for cybersecurity education, cyber defense training, and cyber technology research and development. The HCR provides a safe, secure environment where students, researchers, industry professionals, and government can strengthen theoretical learning alongside practical training on the latest threats and tactics to be better prepared for the realities of defending a network or against an actual attack. The HCR will also be used to train and certify cybersecurity professionals. The HCR was developed by EnterpriseKC.

docs.title: Why It’s Important
docs.text:
The risks we face from cyber-attacks continue to intensify, and no one is immune. The cybersecurity threat landscape touches every industry, every corner of the region, and, as a result, every resident in the region. More troubling is the fact that this country and this region faces a severe shortage of talented workers to combat the threat. Over 572,000 open cybersecurity jobs remain unfilled nationally. Kansas has over 5,300 open cybersecurity jobs across the state, and when we include all of Kansas together with Western Missouri, the number of open cybersecurity jobs jumps to more than 14,000*. One-third of those cybersecurity jobs do not require a 2-year or 4-year degree.

In addition, lack of real-world work experience is the number one challenge identified by industry when hiring new cybersecurity graduates across all education pathways. Graduates – even those holding cybersecurity certificates may have the theory down, but actually putting it into practice is something else entirely.

*As of March 2024*

docs.text: Here we will explain each section within the user interface in detail.

docs.title: Dashboard
docs.text:
Your “home” screen is your user dashboard, which gives you quick at-a-glance information about your earned experience and quick links to other sections of the range.

A snapshot of your profile, including your profile picture and description are displayed under the “Profile Snapshot” section. Next to it, any badges you have earned by achieving specific, related goals are displayed under the “My Badges” section.

The default view is “Progression” and shows current progress in completing any particular learning pathway* displayed under the “Competencies” section.

Quick-access shortcuts for “Account Settings” and “Subscription Info” are also available, and show information relevant to each, by clicking on the appropriate button.

*Learning pathways are described on page [X], under the Learning Pathways section.

docs.title: User Profile
docs.text:
The User Profile section provides additional progress details, statistics, and announcements related to your user profile. Across the top you will find quick-access buttons for competitions and careers (also available in the left-hand navigation bar), as well as an option for providing feedback for anything cyber range related.

The ‘Profile Snapshot’ section shows statistics related to your learning experience such as number of hours spent on the range, courses/labs/assessments completed, and your daily learning streak.

An ‘Announcements’ section displays any site-wide announcements for the HCR, as well as any course-specific or other announcements related to your user profile. ‘In Progress Learning’ will show a summary of courses you are enrolled in and the current progress in each.

The ‘To Do List’ will document any next steps to take in the completion of any courses or modules you are enrolled in.

docs.title: Courses
docs.text:
The courses section allows you to view the various courses that are offered. Courses are searchable using the search bar near the top of the page. You may also filter courses by difficulty level, domain, and job role. Courses are intended to provide a complete learning experience regarding a particular subject or topic.

Courses are organized into categories. Categories include major cybersecurity topics such as malware, network security, and cryptography (among many others). Selecting a particular category shows you all of the courses related to that category. There may also be several additional sub-categories which when selected will narrow the scope of the courses shown. Select a course to view additional details related to it.

Displaying a particular course will also show all of the modules related to it. Modules are individual lessons or activities within a course. They may cover a range of topics, or often are focused on one particular area of interest or use of a particular tool or program.

docs.title: Scenarios
docs.text: Practice your skills in real-world situations through scenario-based modules and delve into free form explore modules to practice and learn in your own way.

docs.title: Leaderboards
docs.text: Check out the leaderboards section to see how you compare to other range users. Users can be ranked by achievements in badges earned, or progress in completing courses. The more you practice and gain experience, the higher you’ll climb!

docs.title: Compete
docs.text:
Competitions are available to test the skills and abilities you’ve gained. Enter a solo competition to tackle challenges on your own, and have your results ranked amongst other competitors. Join a team to compete in cooperative scenarios, or in competitive showdowns. Choose from a variety of competitions such as capture-the-flags (CTFs), red vs. blue team exercises, and more.

Some competitions may require enrollment by your educator or team administrator before they become accessible.

docs.title: Careers
docs.text: The Careers link is your portal to the EKC Talent Exchange. Show off your badges and experience earned on the range to potential employers. See exciting available cyber roles and learn what kind of experience the job poster requires. Use this info to strengthen your skillset and show companies you have the right stuff.

docs.title: Virtual Machines and Networks
docs.text:
The HCR is a simulation environment – the computers and networks connecting them that you will interact with are all ‘virtualized’. That is to say that they are not physical devices; there are no network cables, network devices, monitors, or keyboards (other than your own). These virtual machines (VMs) and virtual networks can be created on the fly, allowing for massive flexibility and endless options for creating simulations. The EKC network that powers the HCR provides unparalleled performance, allowing VMs to be spun up in a fraction of the time as other ranges.

Any module that requires a VM to complete will contain a button. When you click on it, any VMs associated with the module will be started. Within a few moments, you should see the resources become available. Each VM will have an icon associated with it [image placeholder] that when clicked on, will open a ‘console’ view to it in a new tab. Simply click anywhere within this console view to begin interacting with the VM as you would any other computer.

If you begin a lab and are unable to complete it in one setting, any work you have done up to that point will be saved for [update with saved state time] hours. Simply access the lab again, and the VM will be just as you left it. Should you not access the VM within the timeout period, the VM resources will be reclaimed to provide to other users and your work will be lost. Relaunching the lab after this period will start up clean new VMs in their initial state.

When you have finished work in a lab, the VMs and any virtual network resources in use will be reclaimed when you click the [insert ‘complete lab’ button] button. VMs that were in use are ‘destroyed’, meaning any work or information within the VM will be lost, while the resources (RAM, compute, storage) the VM was using will be returned to the EKC network pool.

docs.text: Learning Pathways are collections of courses and may also include stand-alone modules. They are designed as a roadmap to provide curated content to help you reach a specific goal. For example: a Learning Pathway, “Introduction to Cybersecurity”, would be geared towards helping users with little to no cybersecurity experience prepare for an entry level role, whereas a “Cyber Defense Analyst” pathway would contain all the content to help a user obtain that particular work role.
